category.name: Aptitude
category.description: Develop mathematical reasoning and problem-solving skills for competitive exams and interviews.

sub_categories.name: Puzzles
sub_categories.description: Solve logical puzzles, brain teasers, and analytical thinking problems.

exercises.title: Complex Algorithmic Puzzles
exercises.description: Solve complex algorithmic puzzles requiring advanced problem-solving techniques.

tasks.title: State Space Search
tasks.question:
What is the branching factor of a Rubik's Cube search tree?

Consider: How many possible moves can be made from any state
tasks.hint: Think about the number of different moves available at each step

tasks.title: 15-Puzzle Solvability
tasks.question:
What determines if a 15-puzzle configuration is solvable?

Consider: The number of inversions
tasks.hint: Think about the parity of inversions and the position of the empty space
options: The parity of inversions and position of empty space

tasks.title: Magic Square Properties
tasks.question:
What is the magic constant for a 3x3 magic square using numbers 1-9?

Consider: Sum of all numbers divided by number of rows
tasks.hint: Calculate sum of 1+2+...+9 and divide by 3

exercises.title: Advanced Mathematical Puzzles
exercises.description: Solve complex mathematical puzzles requiring deep analytical thinking.

tasks.title: Latin Square Properties
tasks.question:
What is the minimum number of filled cells needed to uniquely determine a Latin square?

Consider: The constraints of Latin squares
tasks.hint: Think about the minimum information needed to complete the square

tasks.title: Knight's Tour Problem
tasks.question:
What is a closed Knight's Tour?

Consider: The knight's movement pattern
tasks.hint: Think about the knight returning to its starting position
options: A tour that visits every square once
A tour that visits every square once and returns to start
A tour that visits half the squares
A tour that uses the shortest path

tasks.title: Graph Theory Puzzles
tasks.question:
What is the minimum number of colors needed to color any map so that no adjacent regions have the same color?

Consider: The Four Color Theorem
tasks.hint: Think about the famous theorem about map coloring
